newsitem.title: UK: London freight sees drop on Panamaxes hit BFI.
newsitem.headline: London freight sees drop on Panamaxes hit BFI.

text.p: Slumping Panamax freight rates dragged the BFI down by its largest margin this year, 31 points to 1361, to equal the lowest index figure seen since January 30.

Caper and Handy-size rates remained barely steady and there was a widespread lack of optimism for prospects in the summer for all categories. The Baltic Handy index managed a minimal improvement of 2 points to 1099 on the strength of firm levels for craned tonnage from the Continent to the Far East, but significantly the trial grain routes US Gulf/Continent and Brazil/Continent not included in the Handy index both fell from $15.50 to 15.31 and $18.75 to 18.56 respectively.

Although the Zennoh berth is expected to be out of action until June/July, the Mississippi is reported to be expected to return to normal levels by early May. a high volume of fixing of vessels ready to load in the river first half May has been seen but rates have still continued to decline. Three US Gulf/Japan fixtures of 54,000 heavy grain were reported for first half May at $22.00 no combo to Halla, Dreyfus and Hanjin, down another 50 cents from Wednesday's level.

It was rumoured Halla were trying to relet their position at $21.00. Transatlantic rates were also grim for owners with Toepfer fixing 59,000 heavy grain St Lawrence/Ghent-Hamburg range at a very weak $8.50 for end April/early May. from E Coast S America Dreyfus were said to be close to fixing Panamax tonnage Plate/Taiwan at an economical rate close to $23.00. In the Pacific grain rates were falling just as rapidly. Continental booked Pan Ocean tonnage (possibly Samjohn Captain) for 54,000 heavy grain Nopac/Taiwan for end April at only $13.00 and Halla took a Yukong vessel (possibly Camarina) for 54,000 heavy grain Nopac/Japan also for end April at $13.25 no combo.

Handy-size activity in grain was limited. Sea Muse 36,000 was linked with Gesuri Lloyd for a heavy grain cargo Plate/Iran at close to $30.00, and Glencore booked 25,000 heavy grain Rio Grande/Malaysia for early May at a weak $33.00. Italgrani were said to have fixed Cleanthes for 25,000 grains Plate/Libya $26.50. New business quoted included Toepfer for a Panamax US Gulf/Holland for 1/10 May, Bunge up to 5m cft grains Mississippi/Holland for 25 April/5 May (2 Panamaxes possibly workable instead), Finagrain 50,000 51' Sao Francisco do Sul and Rio Grande/1-2 ports Malaysia, Indonesia or Thailand, and Andre 25,000 wheat Guaymas/Casablanca 2/9 May.

Caper markets produced few fixtures. Rohstoffhandel booked Cattleya Star for 150,000/10 ironore Tubarao/Rotterdam for 15/30 May at a fairly steady $5.65, but Kleimar were reported to have taken Marshal-class tonnage for 110,000/10 ironore Nouadhibou/Antwerp for April/May at a weak level about $4.05/15 although some reports put the rate as high as $4.50. Cobam were said to have covered about 150,000 tonnes ironore Ponta do Ubu/Rotterdam for 15/30 May but full details were lacking.

Panamax rates generally continued to slide in the East. a couple of modern types were taken for Australian rounds by Japanese charterers at a fairly steady 11,500 daily, but Nordmax 72,500 dwt went to HMM delivery spot Shanghai for a trip via Dalrymple Bay to Hongkong at only $10,500 daily. Similar tonnage was said to be indicating close to $10,000 daily plus $150,000 bonus for delivery Nopac trip Far East. Lleonardo Llembo 75,200 dwt was reported fixed by HMM delivery Japan end April for a coal trip via Queensland to Sweden at between $7,000 and 8,000 daily but some brokers believed the business had failed.
